info.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 04 at 12:23AM EST until February 05 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River Near Fletcher affecting Buncombe and Henderson Counties. .Approximately 3-5 inches of rain have fallen across the upper French Broad watershed over the past 24 hours, causing significant rises along the French Broad River and associated tributaries. The heaviest rainfall has departed the area but additional rounds of light to moderate rainfall are expected through Friday morning. Therefore, it will take many hours for excessive runoff to subside and for tributaries to crest and begin their recession. These high flows are causing the upper French Broad River to exceed bankfull, resulting in isolated nuisance flooding from Horse Shoe to Mills River to Avery Creek. This flooding will primarily impact farmland and boat-access areas. Please stay weather aware tonight and monitor the latest forecasts and stream levels for up-to-date information. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM EARLY THIS MORNING TO TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...French Broad River Near Fletcher. * WHEN...From early this morning to tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Action/Advisory Stage. The French Broad River has exceeded bankfull at the gauge site. Isolated farmland flooding is beginning across the French Broad River Valley from Etowah downstream to Avery Creek upstream of the gauge site. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:46 PM EST Thursday the stage was 9.2 feet and rising rapidly. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest between 10.5 and 11.0 feet this afternoon. - Action/Advisory Stage is 10.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp
